section.title: Present and Future Value with the Force of Interest
section.p: Our next task is to determine how to find the present and accumulated values of cash flows when given the force of interest. This is equivalent to finding the accumulation function A(t) when given the force of interest \delta_t. Since \delta_t is a derivative, it shouldn't surprise you that recovering A(t) from \delta_t involves integration. We aren't going to do this rigorously. Rather, we will use the general principal that as we go from discrete to continuous, we have \sum \rightarrow \int.

assemblage.title: ⚠ Warning
assemblage.p: One note about notation -- we are going to start seeing e raised to complicated exponents. It is customary to use \mathrm{exp}( \ ) in these situations. In other words, e^{f(x)} = \mathrm{exp}(f(x)).

introduction.p: We'll start with a simple example. Suppose 1 is invested in an account that has an annual continuously compounded interest rate of 5% during the first year, 3.5% during the second year, and 6% during the third year.

task.p: Find the accumulated value at the end of the third year.
Find the force of interest \delta_t (don't overthink this!).

assemblage.title: ⚠ Warning
assemblage.p: As we will see, it turns out that having a continuously compounding interest rate of r over a period is equivalent to having a constant force of interest \delta over the period, and \delta = r. For the rest of this book, unless otherwise indicated, we will use \delta for our continuously compounded interest rates (as well as a constant force of interest). Note that when you start preparing for the IFM exam, these notation conventions will change.

introduction.p: Let us generalize this example. Suppose our force of interest \delta_t takes on constant values \delta_1, \delta_2, \ldots, \delta_n during years 1, \ldots, n respectively.

task.p: Find an expression for the accumulation factor in which the base e is written once.

For a general \delta_t (which we will assume is continuous, at least except for finitely many points), in the exponent we have to add up each value of \delta_t for each t. Since we are going from adding up a discrete number of values to a continuum of values, we use the principal that \sum \rightarrow \int Find an expression for the accumulation factor at the end of year n.
Given \delta_t. write an equation for the accumulation function A(t). In addition, find an equation for the present value.

assemblage.title: ⚠ Warning
assemblage.p: We will often have time running to n, and we can write \int_0^n \delta_t dt Other times we have time running to t (and for a specific time, we will use n and t interchangeably). If that is the case, we have to integrate with respect to a variable besides t, such as r: \int_0^t \delta_r dr

statement.p: Show that if \delta_t = \delta is constant, then interest accumulates by compound interest, A(t) = A(0)e^{\delta t}, and \delta = \ln(1+\iota) where \iota is the effective interest rate with a period matching the units of time.

assemblage.title: ⚠ Warning
assemblage.p: This tells us that if we are given a constant force of interest over a period of time, we accumulate via compound interest over that time. You will often see problems in which you are given \delta (as opposed to \delta_t), in which case you can and should assume that \delta is constant.

statement.p: If we have \delta_t = \frac{\iota}{1 + \iota t} what is A(t)? What do you notice?
